History of the Feuds and Conflicts among the Clans in the Northern Parts of Scotland and in the Western Isles . Printed by J . & J . Robertson for John Gillies . Perth , 1780 .
MACCALLUM , Duncan : Co - chruinneacha Dhan , Orain , &c . , &c . Inverness , 1821 .

Tha Croigh is teas is Deididh
An Deidich Ian Luim
Tha fiônâdh gu Biagh
Ann an Cialabh Ian Luim ;
Bha ’ n Fiônâdh ud riamh
Ann an Gialabh Ian Luim .

Ga d ’ tha ’ n oidhche nochd fuar
’ S beag air chadal mo luaidh
Ann am aigneadh , ’ s cha n ’ fhuairead m éididh .

Dol a chreachadh nan srathaibh
Is srathair air a ’ bhliadhnach .
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Is fuath leom céile bhiodh carrach
Is fuath leom cailleach ri posadh
Is fuath leom oiseach gun oran
Is fuath leom och och gun tinneas .
( 2 )

Tha na coin air an eilligh
’ S tha na feidh air an leachduin
’ S iad a feamheadh ri ’ n leigadh
Ris na feadanean glase ;
Chuir mi fear agus litir
Le fios chun a Chaisdeil
Obh obh mar thachair
Ciod a dh ’ fhearaich ’ m Marcus .
( 4 )

36 .
Is tu b ’ fhaicillich ceum
Mu ’ n taice - sa an dé .

Bha mi lathair an latha
’ N robh do bhraithrin is t athair
Far an d ’ fhag iad nan luighe luchd chleoc .
( “ Scottish Gaelic Folk - Poetry ” by Derick S . Thomson , Scottish Gaelic Studies , Vol . VIII , p . 17 ) .

Iad gun iteach gun lìnnidh
Ach mar gheòidh air an spìonadh .
( BGh , ll . 3709 - 3710 )

130 . Cf . :
Ite an eòin léith
Briogadh ’ na déidh .
( BGh , ll . 6342 - 6343 )

152 . ’ n fhàsag : E reads Nàsaig , while in O the form is nasag ( an empty shell ) , and in BGh ( 2nd edn . ) , àsaig ( àsuinn , acfhuinn , tools , apparatus ) . Nàsag = ’ n fhàsag — fàs , empty , hollow .

Foireann air thì ,
Dolaran sìos ,
Galain de ’ n fhìon bhàrcaideach .
( Ibid . , ll . 6375 - 6377 )

De shliochd àrmann Chinn - tìre ,
Iarla Ile agus Rois thu .
( Gaelic Songs of Mary MacLeod , ll . 703 - 704 )

Mar sin ’ san Allt - Eireann ur hero triath Labhar
A dh ’ fhàg Alasdair euchdach gun spéirid ’ s gun labhairt ,
An reubalach breun sin le réisimeid churst .

R . I . A . Dict . ) ; ducorastar Dia deilb mordraige 7 fir boith forsinní Dauid , Ml . 52 , translated “ a form of great ruggedness ” in Thes . Pal . Possibly a gen . of mordrach — cf . aurddrag , erdrach , sprite , spectre . ( Cf . Stories from the Táin , Glossary . ) The second part might then correspond to the second part of erdrach . The first part mor , compositional form of muir ? But cf . R . I . A . Dict . Contribb . s . v . Morrigan , where it is mentioned that the first part has been regarded as cognate with O . H . G . mara and A . S . maere . Cf . Eng . nightmare ( defined in Concise Oxford Dict . as “ female monster sitting upon and seeming to suffocate sleeper , incubus , etc . ” ) , Fr . cauchemar . Note also phrase fulacht na Morrigna ( R . I . A . Dict . fulacht — cooking - pit etc . ) ; mordhrach would represent a later form of mordrach , and so mordhragh ( cf . aurddrag ; g = gh ? ) .

Na leig sibh am baiteal ud Lòchaidh air dhearmad ,
’ N uair a bha sinn le ’ r lannaibh mar choirce ’ gur searbh - bhuain ?

Iain Mùideartach an curaidh
Dh ’ iomair cluich air Lòchaidh .

Dh ’ imich Alasdair fhéin bhuainn
Thuit le baran an Eirinn .

400 . Cf . :
Nam b ’ e do chleachdadh an lùireach
Is claidheamh cùil a ’ chinn aisnich .
( Allan MacDougall , Songs , p . 3 ; cf . pp . 20 , 40 , vv . 3 , 1 )

447 - 448 . Cf . :
Luchd bhualadh nam buillean
Far ’ m bu chruaidh air càch fuireach .
( Mac Talla nan Tùr , p . 76 )

During the Civil War Sir Lachlan Maclean of Duart , who was a staunch Royalist , had paid none of the public dues , as he was of the opinion that the expenses involved by him in equipping and maintaining a force for the King ’ s cause entitled him to withhold payment . After the Royalist forces had been disbanded he had little inclination to pay them to those whom he regarded as usurpers . Argyll bought up all his debts , both public and private , and established a claim against him for £30 , 000 Scots . On his way to negotiate with Argyll , Sir Lachlan was arrested by him in Inveraray and imprisoned in Carrick Castle in 1647 . His health declined and eventually he was prevailed upon by his friends to sign a bond acknowledging his debt to Argyll — this being the sole condition of his liberation ( MacFarlane , Genealogical Collections , Vol . I , pp . 135 - 136 ; History of the Clan Maclean , pp . 175 - 176 ) . It was during Maclean ’ s enforced confinement in Carrick Castle that this poem was composed .

520 . Major — afterwards Lieutenant - Colonel — Menzies , Huntly ’ s captor , is described by James Fraser as “ a base villain ” ( Wardlaw MS . , p . 335 ) . He is known in Gaelic as Crùnair Ruadh nan Cearc , “ Red - haired Crowner of the Hens ” . The term crùnair was applied to one who lifted the ( crown ) rents , some of which were paid in kind . The lowest form of kind in the Highlanders ’ estimation consisted of hens , the “ cain fowl ” by which rents were sometimes paid in part . Hence Crùnair nan Cearc is a term of contempt . A reward of £1 , 000 had been promised to any who should apprehend Huntly , which sum was duly paid to Menzies by the Committee of the Estates . ( See Act of Sederunt of the Committee in the Appendix to William Gordon ’ s History of the Family of Gordon , Vol . II , p . 547 . )

554 . Cf . :
A ’ cur sàraidh air fìon
Is ’ ga leigeadh an gnìomh òircheard .
( Songs of Mary MacLeod , ll . 763 - 764 )

603 . The reference is to the supporters of Charles I , who lost even the right to reside in their own country , prominent among whom was of course Montrose ( Balfour , Historical Works , Vol . IV , pp . 65 - 66 ) , while the Marquis of Argyll , on the other hand , benefited to the extent of £45 , 000 for alleged loss of rent and damage to his property ( A . P . S . , Vol . VI , I , pp . 643 , 675 )

denoted a burden upon land . The càin in Scotland was a fixed payment in kind , the nature of the payment changing in the course of its history . In Old Irish cáin meant originally law , and in the preface to the first volume of the Senchus Mór , a compilation of Old Irish Law Texts , it is described as a law or decision which applied to the whole of Ireland . It was also applied to certain branches of the law such as Cáin Airraith , law of fosterage , etc . ( See Cameron , Celtic Law , pp . 173 - 174 ; Skene , Celtic Scotland , Vol . III , pp . 227 - 229 . ) In 1652 a general assessment of £10 , 000 per month was levied on Scotland to support the army of occupation ( Firth , Scotland and the Commonwealth , p . xxx ) .

Ard leómhann bu mhùinte .
( BGh , l . 3606 )

Gur e abhall an lios so
Tha mise ag iargain .

The Parliamentary Records of the period confirm MacLeod ’ s treachery , and show that he claimed and was granted the reward that the Estates had offered for the capture of Montrose ( A . P . S . , Vol . VI , II , pp . 563 , 568 , 594 ) . The reward , first placed at £250 , 000 Scots , was later reduced to £20 , 000 Scots — Sir Robert Farquhar being commissioned to make the award ( ibid . , p . 560 ; cf . Balfour , Historical Works , Vol . IV , pp . 35 , 36 ) . There is no evidence extant to show whether or not MacLeod ever received this money , but he did apparently receive 400 bolls of meal from Sir Robert

746 . A reference to the surrender of Charles I by the Scots Army to the English Parliament in 1647 . His safety had been ensured conditionally on his signing the Solemn League and Covenant , and this he had refused to do ( Montereul , Correspondence , Vol . I , pp . 163 - 164 ) . The Scots , realising that the Parliament was anxious to secure the King , decided to use him as a means for extracting the arrears of pay which were long overdue them , and they ultimately consented to accept £400 , 000 , half of which was to be paid immediately , and the remainder by instalments ( A . P . S . , Vol . VI , 1 , p . 634 ; Montereul , op . cit . , pp , 353 - 355 , 441 , 444 ) . The Earl of Sutherland was a Covenanter — hence the poet ’ s taunt to his clansman in these lines .

Le mheud ’ s a fhuair mi bhagradh orm ,
Gun d ’ chum e raoir an cadal uam ;
’ S chan ioghnadh mi bhith abartach ,
’ S ann agam a tha chòir .

Cf . :
Mìleadh is fuidheall feachta
ní cóir a gcur cuideachta .

Thuit Eachann Ruadh ann an Inbhir - chéitein
Agus seachd ceud fear de threunfhuil dhìrich .
( Maclean Bards , Vol . I , p . 112 )

Cf . :
An t - Ailpineach dubh fìrinneach
’ Gan dùthchas cian an Srath .
( BGh , ll . 3986 - 3987 )

877 . Cf . :
Bu tu beannachd na tuatha ,
’ S tu nach teannadh iad cruaidh mu ’ n a mhàl .
( Songs of John MacCodrum , ll . 1279 - 1280 )

The text followed is that of T , where the poem is entitled “ Oran le Iain Lom , air dha a chluinntinn an dara Righ Tearlach bhi air a chrunadh ” . From this source derives the version in SO and O , although the latter introduces a number of readings which differ substantially from the original . The eighteenth stanza is an emended version of the eleventh in “ Tùirneal a ’ Chnatain ” ( in Text ) , and vv . 20 , 21 , 23 have been omitted because the Editor objects to their content . The last stanza is also omitted in this version . In I the poem is entitled : “ Oran air Crunadh Righ Tearlach 2d — Le Iain Lom , air dha bhi chomhnuidh ’ n Clachaig ” . This version is related to T , but there are several differences in readings , and four stanzas are not included , viz . vv . 13 , 14 , 15 , 21 . McL MS . 106 supplies six stanzas with no heading , viz . , vv . 1 , 7 , 8 , 10 , 11 , 12 in that order . These are also found in McN¹ with several minor orthographical differences , and three additional stanzas — variants of vv . 3 , 16 , 18 . In this source the poem bears the following heading : “ Oran do ’ n Righ air son an d ’ fhuair Ian Lom £50 pr . ann , a shuidheachadh air ged nach b ’ fhada mheal se e ” . For an English rendering of fourteen stanzas of the poem see C , pp . 168 - 169 .
966 . A grant of £45 , 000 was made to Argyll for maintenance and annual rents in lieu of damage to his property during the Montrose Wars ( A . P . S . , Vol . VI , 1 , pp . 643 , 675 ) .

Beir gu ar n - éibhneas leat Rìgh Seumas
’ S an t - éighre - s ’ a Bhreatainn .
( Fernaig MS . , p . 223 )

Gun robh maoim air do naimhdean
Anns gach camp dhiu ri shireadh .

Tha nas mò orm mar iongnadh
An dràsd anns an leum so .

Có an neach ’ ga bheil sùilean
Nach gabhadh d ’ a ionnsaigh
Mar tha a ’ choille air a rùsgadh ?
( BGh , ll . 3698 - 3700 )

Gaisgeach air ghaisgeach , is laoch ri laoch .
( Nicolson , Gaelic Proverbs , p . 155 )

Cf . :
Gur a h - iomadh laoch dòrngheal
Chaidh an òrdugh mu d ’ bhrataich .
( Maclean Bards , Vol . I , p . 43 )

The text followed is that of McL MS . 154 , where the poem is entitled : “ An Ciaran Mabach , Do Ghilleaspuig Ruadh Mac Mhic Dhonuill ” . The version in G appears to be derived from this source , although there is one different reading in the text , and the alternative readings in McL are not supplied . A different version is found in NL and JS , with the same sequence of lines and stanzas . Both sources omit the chorus and vv . 6 , 8 , and there are no substantial differences in readings . No title is given but in each version there is a brief introductory note : “ Gheibh ŭ , n , lorg sho mar dŭbhuirt ughdar chŭmhidh , agŭs no mŭrtarrin ar fhogra e dhŭich , ar son no bha e grait ŭmp , n , sheol dŭsg chŭir air a Chinnidh dhonillich ar fad , gŭ dheanibh , mar rin̅n̅ Sir Shemŭs , s , chŭir shin gean̅n̅ ar Ian lom , a ghra mar chi ŭ romhad arda hseol̅l̅ , - gŭ dŭthrachdich , tabhairt taing do dhia mar hachir do na mŭrtarin ” ( NL ) .
1598 - 1600 . Some of the vocables may or may not carry any meaning , e . g . có , sin ( seinn , SO ) , calman comhdhail ( codheal , McL , G , = co - gheal ? ) .

1649 . Cf . :
Tha mise fo ghruaim
’ S gun mi ’ n caidreabh a ’ chuain ;
Cha chaidil mi uair air chòir .
( BGh , p . 217 )

Gu bràth cha till
Gun téid na gill a chur leotha .

Cf . :
Leat bu mhiann mar cheol cluaise
Feadain bhinn nan sgal cruaidhe .
( MacDougall , Songs , p . 119 . See also BGh , l . 2319 )

Bhuinnig iad baile ’ s leth Alba…
Bhuinnig iad latha Chath Gairbheach .
( MacCodrum , Songs , ll . 1903 , 1905 )

Cràiteach glé phianmhor
So dh ’ fhàg mi gu h - iargainneach tinn ,
Tha còrr is dà bhliadhna
On a thàrmaich so ’ n giallaibh mo chinn .
( MC , p . 69 )

A luchd nan ceann - bhearta cràbhaidh
Thionndaidh falachd a ’ chrùin ruibh .

2215 . In 1640 the Earl of Argyll proceeded to Atholl with a force of 5 , 000 men , to enforce the submission of John Murray , first Earl of Atholl , the father of the subject of this poem , who had hitherto held aloof from the Covenanters . Atholl despatched commissioners of peace to meet him , undertaking to support the Covenant , but Argyll refused to negotiate with him unless he appeared in person . Having been assured of “ safe access and recess ” , Atholl duly presented himself before the Earl , but was taken prisoner ( Hist . MSS . Com . Report XII , App . 8 , p . 25 , No . 62 ; Guthry , Memoirs , p . 64 ; Spalding , Trubles , Vol . I , p . 271 ) . He appeared before the Committee of Estates , and was released only after the payment of £10 , 000 Scots , and a promise to join the Covenanters with a regiment of 500 men ( Balfour , Historical Works , Vol . II , p . 380 ) . This is probably the iasad referred to in l . 2100 .

He then proceeded to Edinburgh to apply for Government aid against the Macleans , but as his mission there did not meet with the success which he desired , he set out for London where he hoped to receive such assistance as he required from John Maitland , Duke of Lauderdale , who was in collusion with him . After several months ’ delay the dispute was remitted to three members of the Privy Council , and in June 1676 the matter came up for consideration . The Earl charged Maclean with a debt of over £27 , 000 Sterling , and a year later a decision was given in favour of Argyll ( History of the Clan Maclean , p . 187 ; Lauder of Fountainhall , Historical Notices , Vol . I , p . 108 ; Willcock , A Scots Earl , pp . 198 - 199 ) .

Rìgh gur muladach thà mi
Siubhal iomall mo shràidean
’ S nach fhaic mi fear - turuis nan làirig a Dùn - éideann .
( v . 1 )

Là eil ’ ann an Coille Chnagaidh
Dh ’ fhalbh MacAidh ’ s gun d ’ fhàg e bhagaids .
( Songs , ll . 1785 - 1786 )

Bha Dòmhnall an Dùin
Gu dlùth air uilinn a ’ bhlàir .
( T , p . 141 )

Writing to Breadalbane from London on 3rd December 1691 , Stair says : “ By the next I hope to hear that these people are come to your hand or else your scheme of mauling them … the hardness of these people and their ungratefulness to you makes me plainly see that there is no reckoning on them but delenda est Carthago ” ( ibid . , pp . 51 - 52 ) . An indication of his sense of guilt is reflected in his endeavour to bribe the survivors of the massacre into silence concerning the part he himself played in it ( ibid . , p . 109 ) . He is described by a contemporary as being “ cunning as a fox , wise as a serpent , but as slippery as an eel ” ( Macky , Memoirs of Secret Services , p . 119 ) .

Is mise bhiodh gu h - aighearach
Nam faighinn mar a dh ’ iarrainn
An ceann thoirt de Mhac Cailein
Agus fail air Mac Iain Riabhaich .

Mac a pheathar — fath an euchd —
Comh - cheangailt ’ ris air dhà ghleus ;
A chliamhain ’ fheoil agus ’ fhuil ,
Dh ’ imich d ’ a dheòin gu dhi - chrùnadh dhuinn .

2640 . Cf . :
Bha ’ m mac aluinn - s ’ a bh ’ aig Dàbhaidh
Gu h - àrdanach , gòrach
Le bhi cathachadh air athair
’ S an t - abhairsear d ’ a sheòladh ,
Thug Dia bàirigeadh thar chàich as ,
Bho dh ’ fhàilig e ordugh - s ’ ;

2670 . Cf . :
Bidh sannt naoinear air aon mhnaoi gun sliochd .
A childless woman has the greed of nine .

Al . :
Bidh sannt nan seachd sagart anns a ’ mhnaoi gun laogh gun luran .
A childless woman has the greed of seven priests .
( Nicolson , Gaelic Proverbs , p . 66 )

The text derives from McL MS . 154 , which bears the title : “ Oran an aghaidh an Uinioin ” , footnote Uinein , bracket reading aonuich ( = aonaidh ? ) . This is the source for the version in G ; GlB and O are based on the latter .

2918 . That Scotland had been sold for English money was a common sentiment at this time ( Duke of Portland ’ s MSS . , p . 256 ) . In August 1706 the Queen gave a loan of £20 , 000 to the Scottish Government . Of that sum over £12 , 000 ( the stràic off the top of the bushel referred to in the text ) was claimed by the Duke of Queensberry as Commissioner , for official expenses , and the rest was to be devoted to arrears of salaries and general expenses . The loan was to be acknowledged in an Act of Treasury , but lest this transaction should be misconstrued if noised abroad , Queensberry and those chiefly concerned , notably Seafield , Mar and Loudoun , induced Godolphin the Treasurer to suppress the Queen ’ s letter to the Treasury announcing the loan , and to consent that the money should be secured only on the personal acknowledgement of the Treasurer - Depute . In 1711 a Committee was appointed under Tory auspices to enquire into public accounts , and Lockhart , one of its members , states that certain individuals were paid to whom no arrears were due , and that others established fresh claims when the Equivalent was distributed ( Cobbet , Parliamentary History , Vol . VI , pp . 1110 - 1115 ; Lockhart , Memoirs , pp . 262 - 272 ) . For a full criticism of Lockhart ’ s accusations see Mackinnon , Union of England and Scotland , pp . 342 - 345 .

Cha bu ghaiseadh ’ bu mhiann
Le cinn ghlasa nan sgiath
Air an leacainn mu ’ n iath do chrann .

Chuir sibh Hurry ’ s a dhaoine
Air an ruaig a bha daor dhaibh ,
Nuair a bhruchd sibh maraon do na chomhail .

Mi nam shuighe ’ n srath ardthuil
’ G amharc cuideachd* Thighearn ’ Adai ( *Buigheann written above )
Cha b ’ e mo chuideachd mar b ’ abhaist an sprod .

Gar ’ n tigeadh gin as do ’ n choig céud .

McL 129 :
